I jumped in a cab which cost ¬£5 but this was only because I had heavy luggage - otherwise its about a 10 min walk to the hotel.Check InFast, friendly and efficient. Nice reception area, clean and bright with a large seating area (also used for meals) and a bar.1 lift was out of order so it was a wait but negligible.StaffAlways happy, friendly and smartly dressed. I didn't come across one miserable staff member in 3 days from the cleaning staff to the concierge - they were all excellent.RoomI was on the 6th floor and the room was small and basic. Clean, Tidy and very comfortable. Hanging space, TV, shelving for clothes. Hairdryer. No in room safe but there are some in the foyer to use.Bathroom had a lovely shower with small sink area and toilet.FoodBreakfast was excellent. Great choice of cereal, fruit, toast and condiments, cooked breakfast. Self service.Even though I had to leave extra early there was enough of a selection to make sure I ate properly each day.Pricing¬£112 per night for 2 adults, this is approx and does vary The bar was reasonably priced for London.LocationNear the Excel, the DLR and tube (Jubilee Line from Canning town via DLR) So very accesble to most areas.ScoreSo overall for Hotel accommodation 8/10Food 7/10Staff 9/10Concierge 10/10Bar 8/10Internet Cost 1/10 (ridiculous)I would totally recommend this hotel if you are after somewhere friendly, clean and comfortable. For the Excel it is easily accessed and if you are attending an event there - perfectly positioned. Lovely staff, Great hotel! Thank you Holiday Inn!

Me and a mate stayed here for 1 night for the MCM London Expo at the ExCeL centre. We only payed ¬£80 in total which really surprised me for such a sought after location right beside the amazing Olympic Park and the very convenient Westfield Stratford City shopping centre only 5 minutes walk away!We were allowed to check in from 3 PM the day we arrived as my mate was incredibly shattered from the overnight bus we had the night before and being on the move from about 6 AM non stop! After he crashed the bed we went to the brilliant Westfield centre which is packed full of pretty much every shop you can think of, the restaurants there all look delicious and the variety is vast!The breakfast in the morning was pretty good too, I didn't personally have a lot as I was going to be meeting a lot of friends and having many (Non Alcoholic) drinks and Japanese snacks with them! It certainly filled my mate up for the day who was full right up to our trip into Chinatown! I stuck to the fairly decent range of Continental Breakfast stuff and yes, there is a standard selection of Cooked Breakfast too!Check In/Out was quick and easy and you couldn't complain at all about the quality of service we were offered.There are some cosplayers and Expo-goers out there who complain about the lack of hotels to the ExCeL and their extortionate cost but this hotel is an ideal location for both before and after thanks to the multitude of restaurants at Westfield!I'd certainly use it for the next convention in May 2013!

Stayed here with my son who is living in London, close to Stratford tube station and Westfield, few mins walk. Hotel room clean and everything we needed, breakfast was lovely, so much choice and was able to check out later than required without a problem, will def stay again.

My boyfriend and I stayed in this hotel for the weekend 26th-28th of October.We went to a concert at the O2, this hotel is an excellent location for the O2 - it only takes 15 minutes to get there door-to-door.  Stratford station has links with the Jubilee & central lines (the DLR is around there too), so it is relatively quick to get to central London - Oxford Circus, Holborn etc.The hotel is very close to Westfield shopping centre and the Olympic Park (although we did not visit these).The hotel itself was very clean, nice size bedroom & bathroom.  Breakfast consisted of continental options as well as cooked and fruits, and was very nice.Staff were helpful and friendly.  One of the hotel lifts was not working, but as the hotel is only 5 floors, this was not an issue.  Road traffic at night also wasn't an issue.Overall, an excellent base for what we wanted.  Would stay here again.

I stayed her for 2 nights starting October 19th, as I was going to a convention at the Excel.Because we were running late for our appointment the reception staff let us throw our cases in the lockup and said that they would sort our room keys out when we got back. Which they did, no problem.Our room was very nice and clean, with white bedding, choice of pillows and with large towels. Good hot shower too and toiletries supplied free of charge from reception if you should forget to bring anything.Not much room to put any clothes away, but I don't suppose guests stay long enough for that anyway.Our mistake was not asking for a room away from the High Street. The noise of traffic and emergency services was all through the night.  To be expected I'm sure on a busy London street.The free breakfast was to be praised.  I'v stayed at hotels with free"breakfast" but none as good as this. The bacon, eggs and sausage were good, choice of cereals, fruit, lovely fresh bread and croissants, top name yoghurts, and a first class coffee machine. The orange juice in the machine was a bit tasteless, but the rest of the breakfast made up for that.We didn't eat in the hotel at night so can't comment on their meals.We did try to order coffees at the bar one evening but the staff kept talking together and wandering off so we gave up. Reception staff though were very nice and helpful.We were about an 8 minute walk to the train station for our train to the Excel. They were working on the line so had to transfer to a bus at Canning Town.  But no problem.Overall, yes, I would stay here again if in the area. And would book again through Laterooms as we got a deal.

column9: Nice hotel, shame about the staff.
column10: We stayed here from the 19th to the 22nd of October 2012 and it's safe to say it was a once in a lifetime experience. The hotel itself was clean and modern and the rooms pleasant, but this is where the pleasantries end. There are only two lifts for the whole building, one of which was out of order and had been for some time. The staff seemed in no hurry to remedy the situation when questioned, much to the annoyance of many of the guests. This meant that everyone checking out at 11am were waiting on the one lift. We reported the air conditioning in our room did not cool the room down, it only blew out heat. The staff replied that they had changed the settings in readiness for winter and that all the air con units were linked therefore this could not be changed. This meant the hotel was horribly hot all the time. It would be easy to suggest to open the windows, but as the hotel is directly situated next to a busy road this made sleeping almost impossible. We had to borrow a fan from reception. The food at the restaurant was also a sore point. My wife has an allergy to cheese, she ordered a salad which had no cheese on the menu. It came covered in it. We complained and the waiter explained it might take a few minutes to make a fresh dish. After 30 minutes we gave in and asked for a refund. My wife then ordered tea and biscuits, the biscuits were a month out of date. When we took them back the staff seemed to find it amusing and offered no apology just simply replaced them. Having returned from NY last week and saw how the Americans do hospitality this hotel was an embarrassment, made worse by the fact that the hotel had many Americans staying there. The staff in general had no inclination to make anyone's life more comfortable. When people (and there were plenty) complained they seemed to listen, brush it off and do nothing about it. A poor show by all involved.

column9: A well-situated, well-kept hotel within reach
column10: Our family stayed for a week in October, and were very pleased with what we got. As both games (Olympic and Paralympic) were already over, there was no rush and no construction work, thus accessibility was excellent as well. The hotel is well situated as it is just a short walk from a DLR station (Stratford High Street) and within a 10min walking range of the Stratford main tube station (Jubilee and Central) as well the massive Westfield mall worth visiting. Trips to the city centre didn't take long so Stratford was also easy to reach. Lots of convenience stores just a few steps away.All staff were very friendly and helpful. We immediately felt at peace when we checked in and got to our double bed + sofabed room. The sofabed however, which had been made in anticipation of our 2,5yr old son, was so high that we couldn't have slept peacefully knowing the kid could fall while sleeping, so we collapsed the sofa and laid the mattress down on the floor. A separate children's bed would have been more proper but we didn't have the choice of choosing one when booking through our travel agency, I don't even know if they have children's beds, but this was just a minor issue. The double bed was far too soft for my back (having got adjusted to a futon) but again, that's just a personal preference. Things that we did feel strange about were the door to the adjacent room, the strange tap on the bathroom sink and the rather high pricing on wifi access.The door, I would imagine, is useful if you are two families or a bunch of friends traveling and want to share rooms, but otherwise I couldn't think of a reason to put us there. Noise was emanating from the other room each morning and night, and was a bit disturbing to hear what others were talking about. I can imagine the guests in the other room were also disturbed to hear our talk and the cry of our baby..The sink tap was really weird - it drizzled/sprinkled/sprayed water in a shower sort of fashion as opposed to a regular water stream in all the rest of the world. I would imagine the taps have been made so to spare on conserve water, but it sure made washing hands really frustrated as the sink area was wet all over after just washing hands. I asked about this from the cleaning maids but was told all taps are like this and there's nothing they can do about it.Otherwise.. our room was very clean and cozy, with most amenities you needed - a water kettle, instant coffee and tea, a TV and so on. We felt very good staying there. Wifi access was made too expensive. Most european hotels these days (it's 2012 after all) give either free wifi access or a 24-hour access card for a few coins, but here you got 30mins for a few pounds (can't remember how much but several pounds anyhow) which I feel is expensive, and the 24-hour card was also very expensive. Breakfast was the usual continental fare, though without oatmeal/porridge or any salad, but a good one none the less. Food could be taken back to the room (since our kid was sleeping and didn't wake up for breakfast) which was nice.A highlight was, however, when our son got thrilled by a maid servicing the breakfast (and our room for a day or two), who gave cookies and played peekaboo with our son, so that was really great - she even said she'll miss us when we had to leave :(Just the small details I pointed out earlier would have made this visit perfect, but even now this was a very good visit which after all left us smiling when we left, so I'd return any day if I were out and about :)

column9: Good base for a visit to the Olympic Park or 02
column10: Well placed hotel within a short taxi ride of Stratford Station and the Olympic Park. We used it as a base for a visit to the 02. Staff very helpful. Room excellent, large, modern and clean with all the amenities including an excellent bathroom. The rack price was almost 5 times the actual price we paid online - not sure I would have paid the full price. Not within easy walking distance of the station due to the development of the artery roads and walkways that have now embraced Startford for the Olympic development. Buffet breakfast offered a wide range of fare, damned by the usual rather tasteless scrambled egg as the only egg option.Overall more than adequate for the price we actually paid.

My wife and I got a last-minute deal on this hotel that was around ¬£40 cheaper than the standard rate - not bad!!!  A decent location not far from both Stratford station and Stratford High Street Docklands Light Railway station, we were warmly received by the staff. They were helpful in advising us of somewhere to eat given we arrived late and the restaurant was closed. The room itself was fine - spacious, usual tea and coffee making facilities and a clean, reasonable sized bathroom. The only downside was the bed mattress felt like a glorified quilt and was spongy-soft - not so good.  Breakfast the following morning was good - a varied choice to cater for all tastes! Whilst the food wasn't 'top-end', given it was included in the price it was fine. The Olympic Park was a short stroll away - alas parts of it are being flattened given the games are now over - as is the vast Westfield Shopping Centre for all shopaholics! Would definitely stay again - a good option if you don't fancy the rip-roaring racket of London but want to be in striking distance!

column9: Excellent hotel let down by the breakfast
column10: On arrival the hotel is smart and modern with helpful and professional reception staff.My room was clean and spacious with good amenities.  The bed was comfortable but had the standard, awful 'Holiday Inn' cheap pillows.  It wasn't a huge issue but something that could easily be addressed.The bathroom was very clean and spacious.  The shower cubicle was large and very clean, the shower was hot and fairly strong which is good.  One thing that I would comment on is that the shower floor was quite slippy, not an issue for me but could be a safety issue for someone who is elderly or is infirm.  The breakfast was the let down for my stay.  The hotel was full so the bar/breakfast area was quite cramped.  I really don't like the 'bench' arrangement of the tables but can understand why it is necessary.  The breakfast itself was a huge disappointment, the sausages were strange, why not just provide 'regular' sausages which will appeal to a wider audience.  There was scrambled egg and beans, both of which I don't eat and bacon which was covered in the white 'scum' that you get on cheaper bacons.  To be fair it tasted okay but wasn't hot despite being kept under lights.  The buffet part of the breakfast was limited so I ended up with just toast and fruit; I like to have a full breakfast when I'm on business as I often can't get a proper lunch.Checkout was easy and quick and again the staff were excellent.I would certainly recommend the hotel but, given the choice, would go elsewhere for breakfast.

I spent 1 night at the Holiday Inn Express with a couple of friends on a girly night out..  We booked a double room with a sofa bed for the 3rd person.  On arrival I was impressed with the service provided at reception.  Although I hadn't made the booking they had my name on the system and let me have the room key without any probing.  The room was fine for the 3 of us, with the sofa bed already made up.  The bathroom was very clean with a spacious shower.  My only criticism was that the bed was far to soft, my friend and I actually met in the middle of the bed.  Luckily we are very good friends and have known each other for over 30 years.The cost of the room was ¬£125 for the night which included breakfast.  Unfortunately the beans, sausages and bacon was cold which was a shame.  We were able to fill up on the pastries and toast so luckily didn't go hungry.Yes I would stay there again.  As I know Stratford very well, we choose that holiday because of the location.  Walking distance to Westfield, the main train station and all the local bars and restaurants. And to top it off we were given an hour and a half extension on our check out time.  Overall a lovely stay.

column9: Good hotel, shame about price due to Paralympics.
column10: We stayed here for two nights when visiting the Olympic Park. We stayed in a room with double bed and fold out sofa bed. Having two kids (aged 2 and 4 months), we had plenty of room and enjoyed our stay. The hotel felt modern and clean with a good breakfast. We were able to check in over an hour early due to the room been ready. We parked at the hotel as the thought of taking the tube with two kids and prams etc seemed too daunting. We got charged ¬£40 for 2 nights which seemed a little steep but worth it. The only down side was the price. I understand the Olympics were on but at ¬£175 per night I felt this was too steep.

We stayed at the Holiday Inn Express for 1 night during the Paralympics. The hotel is well situated for both transport links and the Olympic Park/Westfield Shopping Centre. The hotel is about 8 minutes walk from Stratford Main Station, 3 minutes walk from the DLR, 5 minutes walk from the Olympic Park and 10 minutes walk from Westfield.The hotel was clean and modern with small but well appointed rooms. Our room 427 overlooked a courtyard at the back of the hotel and was nice and quiet. We did not notice any noise from the traffic which is always a bonus in London. The bed was soft but comfortable and the water in the bathroom was hot and plentiful. We did not use the WiFi because 3G coverage was pretty good in our room on the O2 network. There was an additional charge for using WiFi. We also noticed that our floor had an ironing room which we did not use. There was also tea/coffee making facilities in the room.Breakfast was complimentary and served until 10:30. The selection and quality was fine for a quick breakfast with hot food available on the buffet counter.The reception desk employees were polite and helpful at both check-in and check-out.We really could not find fault with the hotel, other than it was a little pricey because of the Paralympics but I am sure you get a better rate at other times of the year. Clearly when you check into a Holiday Inn you are not expecting 5 star luxuries but it did exceed our expectations and "did what it said on the tin".There was a handy Tesco Metro supermarket 2 minutes from the hotel that was open until 23:00.

This hotel is only a short walk (10 minutes) from Stratford rail and bus terminal. Westfield Stratford City is just a stroll away. Apparently this has just had an extensive expansion and refurbishment, with 153 rooms.I booked through the Priority Clubs site and was charged ¬£198 for a twin room for one night ‚Äì it was the Paralympics period ‚Äì sorry, Holiday Inns ‚Äì you were making a fast buck!!!We were well received at reception and allocated a room on the second floor. The public areas are clean and bright. The room was the usual size for this brand of hotel with 2 single beds, desk unit and wardrobe unit. The tv was 29‚Äù with a freeview service, the hospitality tray was perfunctory, but the room was clean. The bed was soft, but the linen was clean and crisp. The bathroom is small, with the outer door capable of separating off the toilet from the rest of the bathroom ‚Äì useful. Toiletries are based on wall mounted dispensers. Lighting levels are ok. The curtains give adequate but not complete black-out and the window does not shut out traffic noise which was intrusive.Breakfast was served in the lobby (which doubles as a Bar) with a choice of scrambled eggs, crispy bacon or sausages and fresh coffee including espresso and cappuccino and fruit, cereals, yoghurts and various breads. It was self service but most things were readily available and well presented.

This was an interesting stay at the Holiday Inn Express in Stratford. We stayed one night during the period of the Paralympic Games, as it is adjacent to the Olympics site in Stratford (London).Firstly, the staff were very helpful and pleasant; the room was clean, just as it should be.However, the rate was ¬£256 ($400) for the two of us for one night b&b through their own website (normally c.¬£76-$120/night). Clearly some profit-taking was going on for the period of the Paralympic Games. For comparison, when we stayed at a hotel in Weymouth for the Olympic sailing events, the hotel rate was unchanged, in spite of heavy demand. For that price we had one bath towel between the two of us (maybe they were so busy the supply had run out). Noisy aircon, but it could be switched off. In addition, we ordered a very standard dinner about 7.00pm with no-one in front of us; only one family had already had their meal delivered. It took around 40 minutes for ours to arrive. Maybe the Chef had run out of fish, but the load on the kitchen seemed to be virtually non-existent.In the morning at breakfast the place was full of visitors, volunteers, media and officials for the Olympics ‚Äì the breakfast buffet was fine, with a good choice.So there were mixed feelings about our stay. I hope the issues we experienced were just because of the Olympic Games. However, for the price, we did feel we should have had gold-medal treatment. Incidentally there is a good Tesco Express convenience store near to the hotel ‚Äì turn right out of the front door and walk along the road c. 200 yards, and across a road junction, to find it.

We stayed here for Paralympic Opening Ceremony and had great views of Olympic park but we asked for a non smoking room and we got a smoking room that stank of smoke. Breakfast was great. Booked online through holiday inn website

stayed with family  and  was happy with our stay.  the staff were very friendly and  helpful .  breakfast was good   -  the only downfall was that  was a bit noisy  at night times and maybe i would put that down to it being a small hotel .

We had to make a last minute dash to London and stay on the East side, so this seemed like an ideal location. In actual fact the hotel is located near not much really - I guess you could say that the Olympic Park is near, as is the Westfield shopping mall, but thats about it from what I could see. It's probably a 10 minute walk fron the DLR railway station which you will need to visit anywhere in the Capital.However, this is a clean, well presented hotel with courteous staff. Everything is sort of 'compact' and it had the smallest family room that we've ever stayed in, but it was clean and in good order. The beds were a joke - as soft as a sponge, the type where you roll into the middle, but did have a selection of pillows of different density. The aircon didn't seem to make any difference, it just whirled away.At time of booking and at check-in we specifically asked for a quiet room because we had a very busy couple of days. We were allocated a room on the first floor at the rear of the hotel and everything seemed fine....until 2.15am when we were woken by some noisy builders on a tea/smoke break. A call to reception eventually got them moving, that was until 3.00am when they had another break. A further irate call to reception was needed. As you can imaging, with an early start we were really tired in the morning. The front desk were apologetic but this shouldn't have been allowed to happen in the first instance.Breakfast was a self-service continental affair but it wasn't obvious if the cooked items were also included or were extra.So there we have it - the hotel was OK but let down for us by some small problems that shouldn't have happened. And, why the piped music outside the hotel?

column9: lovely and clean!!! and great value for money
column10: This is Short but sweet.!!!!Great hotelGreat staffGreat roomGreat breakfastGreat deal!!!You wont be disappointed!!!!Everything on your doorstep!!!!!PLEASE DO NOT SMOKE IN THESE ROOMS!!!! ALARM WENT OFF AT 5.30

Stayed 2 nights in this hotel & would recommend it highly! We arrived in the UK early in the morning at 9am & arrivied to Stratford by bus (National Express) & was dropped off at the Westfield Shopping Centre .. hotel was 5 min walk away, went to drop our bags off & the lovely lady on reception told us we could check in as our room was ready & we could have complimentary breakfast that morning aswell! .. after travelling all night, we were delighted! Room was lovely, standard but for the price we payed.. best value yet! Bed was comfortable, don't know why people are so picky like a review below saying the beds are too soft.. i had a great nights sleep & didn't fall in the middle! haha! Breakfast in the morning was fab.. great choice from cereal, fruit, croissants, buns, full english breakkie incl tea/coffee & juice.  All staff are so friendly & helpful.. great credit to the hotel! The metro/train station was right beside the shopping center so again just a mere 5 min walk.. around 8 stops to get to oxford street so bout  half hour.. perfect location & hotel overall... will be back very soon :)

after staying in another holiday inn express last week which we found very disappointing, we were a bit wary about our already booked stay in another holiday inn express but neednt have been worried, found this hotel to be great value for money, very clean and modern with excellent friendly staff,complimentary breakfast was fantastic although very busy, excellent location for westfield or olympics, only downside is limited parking which you have to pay extra for although once olympics finish should be easier to park nearby. overall great value for money.

Great location for the Olympics, stayed there for 4 nights and am more than happy to recommend. Breakfast was full English, very nice even though I am not fan of english breakfast. Staff were first class, willing to go the extra mile. A shout out to Joel at front desk who moved us to a better room when we complained about our bathroom. The room was very nice and clean, but A/C can be a bit loud. Mind that this location is 20 minutes away from Oxford Circus by tube. Westfield shopping centre is around the corner, with both high-street shops and lots of eateries.

column9: Good budget hotel, spot on breakfast, great staff
column10: Stayed here for 2 nights during the Olympics, and found the hotel to be fine, with good services, nice beds and clean linens etc. Breakfast was a full English affair, with a good hot selection. Staff were first class throughout and more than willing to go the extra mile

Great location for the ollimpics. Rooms were good and clean. Bet was to soft and we both sank into the midle. Continental breakfast was included as was fine. Had decided to have the full breakfast but once I see the way it looked I declined. Dry and unappetising. Staff were very friendly.

I booked the Holiday Inn Express for the night of the Technical Rehearsal for the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.It's location was ideal, a short walk to the Westfield centre and the Olympic Stadium. I booked a family room, as my daughter and grandchildren were with me to sight-see in London for two days.The room was spacious and spotlessly clean. The staff were welcoming and helpul, the breakfast was more than adequate. All in all a very pleasant stay, a sound night's sleep and an excellent beginning to our second day's excursions. I would recommend it.

column9: Probably the best ever value for money Hotel ever in the world
column10: like new ..well run ..good bedrooms.. great showers ..after a knackering day working for the Olympics this is what you need...i stay a lot in these Hotels and this was good .Breakfast was ok not great however

column9: Excellent Place for a Short Tourist Stay
column10: Holiday Inn Express at Stratford, London, was booked for our European tour at the last moment. But it turned out to be the best one we stayed in during our tour. A new, modern hotel with a clean, sleek look, it had several positives.1. Clean, spacious rooms with modern amenities both in the room and the bathroom. Electric kettle with coffee, tea, milk and sugar satchets were available.2, Courteous and friendly staff. Rescheduling of cab timing was done without any hassle.3. Excellent breakfast with sausages and scrambled egg. Lot of fruits, muffins and English cakes too. The staff always personally asked us whether we needed anything else.4. The best part of the hotel is its location. Ten minutes walk from the Stratford underground/bus/overground rail stations. The metro station housed two lines with the Jubilee line terminating at Stratford. Very well connected to Central London5. With Stratford being in the Olympic 2012 district, the hotel is close to the newly-built Westfield mall. The mall is right above the metro station and a fab place for shopping, eating and hanging out.Top hotel  for short tourist/business stay

column9: Perfect stop over for a business trip
column10: A standard Holiday Inn Express, you can usually rely on them for clean and simple rooms, so this didn't disappoint. Shame that parking is limited and chargeable, but being London, I wasn't entirely surprised. Really close to Westfield Stratford City, within walking distance, and also perfect location to jump onto the tube into Central London.Average breakfast - buffet style, but plenty of selection.

column9: Mainly good - Top Floor is SMOKING
column10: Agents will tell you it is against the law for hotels to provide smoking rooms in London - DO NOT BELIEVE THEM. The fact is that the majority of the world are still smokers and in major international destinations like London the chains simply cannot afford to alienate the majority of their customers in this way. Besides this major point, this hotel was everything you would expect from a new build, Holiday Inn Express so I will concentrate on the few drawbacks we experienced....The cab company they use when you ask for them to call you a car often uses drivers who don't know simple destinations such as 'The Science/Natural History Museum'. Find a local 'hire car' company and ask for a business card then ring them directly yourself rather than ask at reception. Many in the area are both cheap AND excellent.The air conditioning was pretty poor and opening the window to let in cooler air at night meant all the noises from a very busy four lane high street outside (a main route for emergency vehicles with sirens blaring) were also let in.The staff were all willing to be helpful and all requests were met with a smile .... just that some of the staff weren't that great at actually doing what was required ... like providing ice in a bucket for the room, for example.Despite it being only around 9am one of the cleaners (I presume) let themselves into the room without knocking - a simple precaution when entering a hotel room well before checkout time (11 am checkout time by the way - too early, 12:00 would be better, but helpful when asked to keep baggage safe until 2pm)  and causing embarrassment to all concerned.No bath in this room, just a smallish shower with curtain and water temperature that varied from very cold to scalding hot without touching the controls!Although supposedly a budget hotel (granted, at the high end of budget hotels) and booked a month in advance the price was too high for a hotel so far from London centre though this was almost certainly because it is on the doorstep of the new Olympic stadium. Using the overground and underground to get into London proper with a day pass takes about 30-45 minutes at a cost of around ten quid but allow another 20 minutes for the queues to buy tickets at the machines as while we were there 25 - 50% of them had ceased to function by 9am.Last buy not least - the bed in this particular room was WAY too soft. If you suffer from back problems take note!
Room and BReakfast was very good.I was there for business meeting.

column9: Close to tube station, new property, reasonable price
column10: I stayed at the HIE-Stratford a couple of weeks ago, and was pleasantly surprised. This is a fairly new hotel, so you are unlikely to notice any part that seems 'run-down'. I liked 3 things about the HIE-Stratford, and have only 1 suggestion for improvement.As a budget hotel, they run their operations with a limited/skeletal staff, and so at times one might have to wait or actually search for the relevant staff-member! If you happen to be checking in our out at an odd hour (like, say 4.30am) then dont be surprised to see a deserted front desk. Similarly, you may want to ensure that you have the time/patience if thinking of ordering a meal from their menu -- it does take time!What still makes this hotel stand out is (a) a very friendly and helpful staff, (b) superb location, and (c) all this at a fairly reasonable price, given that we are talking about London!The HIE-Stratford is located about 7-8 minutes walking distance from the Stratford tube (underground) station, so you are well-connected with the City (a few stations away). Right next to the station, but after exiting on the other side (Westfield Stratford), are multiple shopping malls as well as the 2012 Olympic arena. Those interested in getting a view of the O2 Arena should go to the top floor of John Lewis - it has a viewing deck with binoculars!To get to the HIE, once you reach Stratford tube station, come out of the exit that says 'Stratford Centre' (the other side exit goes toward 'Westfield Stratford'), turn right (you will walk by an old steam engine called 'Robert') till, in about a minute, you reach what looks like a T-junction and a busier road (this is the High Street). Take a right and keep walking. You will see a white-and-red building on the opposite side ('Poland House') and a small white building declaring itself to be a part of the Univ of East London (called 'Duncan House') on your side of the road, and shortly thereafter you will cross Travelodge. The next building on your side of the street will be the HIE.I had an enjoyable stay at the HIE Stratford and may stay again!

column9: Great connectivity, nice staff, good food
column10: I stayed in this Hotel for over 15 days and experienced what others might not know about the hotel. I tried many things from the dinner menu and was never disappointed with the quality. The free breakfast which came along with the room price was great and the staff service was excellent. Very much recommended for business users, and solo travel. Couples, friends and families might consider it for budget travelling. Walking distance to Stratford station makes it very accessible for every kind of traveler.

Our 5th floor room was remarkably spacious and the bathroom was excellent. We asked for the quietest room possible, as the hotel is on a major A-road, and the staff responded perfectly giving us a room away from the road. Breakfast was merely adequate, as expected. The soft mattress was the only disappointment.

column9: Possible alternative hotel outside the city centre
column10: This hotel is situated about half a mile or so from the Stratford railway station.  It is well linked to various parts of London either by the Central or Jubilee tube lines, the Docklands Light Railway network and main line railway.  It is a bit of a hike down from the station and you might want to be careful of a night as the area might be a tad worrying!What of the hotel?  Well, it is fine.  I stayed in a room with two single beds at the back of the hotel - quieter, I suspect than the front which faces a main road.  I was woken once or twice by noises from outside - bottles being moved and that kind of thing.  The room was on the first floor, so noises filtered up from the bar as well.The room was ¬£175 for the night.  This included breakfast and free internet access.  Hugely expensive, of course, but beggars cannot be choosers in London and I did book relatively late.  The Olympics were only three weeks away, so maybe that explains why the rate was so high.  Believe it or not, it was still relatively cheap compared to comparable properties nearer the middle of town.

Stayed at this hotel on two seperate occassions during June 2012. First room I had on the 5th floor was excellent, appeared very recently decorated, comfortable and well equipped. Second time I stayed was on the 4th floor this room was not quite the same standard as the earlier room Id stayed in. Little grubbier and furnishing appeared older etc.However, what really impressed me about this hotel was the absolute professionalism and friendliness of the staff. The reception and restaurant/bar staff could not do enough to look after you and they made it a real pleasure to stay at this hotel.The food was excellent with a small but very tasty menu, the hot breakfast only consisted of scrambled egg, sausage and beans so maybe little room for improvement ther but overall you cant go wrong with this hotel.The location is no more than a 10 minute walk from Stratford rail/bus station and overlooks the Olympic Park.

column9: Nice - but a really bad bed
column10: Since this hotel is rather new (maybe 1-2 years old), everything looks very clean, nice and new (except the couch in our room that had some not very nice looking stains on it).The mattress of the queen bed was way too soft. When you laid down, your body had the form of a U. It also felt like a waterbed - if you moved your leg, the whole bed started wobbling. It did not really help to find out that it was not really a bed, but more of an extracted couch with a (soft) mattress on it. The (other) couch in the room looked exactly the same, just not extracted and with no mattress on it.When we asked the very friendly staff to get a harder mattress or at least another room, they said all the mattresses were the same in every room (they did not have an extra mattress) and that they unfortunately could not do anything about it (but she said there were many complaints about these soft mattresses and that the hotel was already looking for harder ones).The included breakfast buffet was good (though it almost did not have any fruits), mostly because of the cappuccino machine and the freshly squeezed orange juice machine.Overall it was a very clean hotel with a friendly staff but - if you spend the whole day on your feet walking through London, it is better to find a hotel where you sleep well and not wake yourself up constantly by moving just a leg or an arm.

column9: Close to the Olympic Park and Westfield
column10: I was on Olympic business and needed a convenient and reasonably priced hotel close to Stratford.  THe Holiday Inn Express fitted the bill exactly and I was not disappointed.  The reception staff were charming and helpful; the room (at the back overlooking the Olympic site, if you ignore the houses inbetween) was okay.  It was clean, nicely decorated and the bathroom was spick and span.  I liked the labels on the pillows giving a choice of soft or firm and the bed was comfortable.Breakfast should have been served from 7.30 on Sunday morning but, for whatever reason, possibly because there were quite a few guests on the same mission as me, everything was up and running by 7.00, which was very much appreciated.  The buffet choices were, again, okay not outstanding, but this isn't a 5 star luxe destination and within its remit I was very satisfied.

column9: Reasonable price near the West Field Mall
column10: Stayed here for a few days. The location was very convient, was able to get to my business meeting using the stratford station nearby that connects to the subway abd DLR. While at work my family was able to enjoy the new west field mall. Note: breakfast in hotel is limited so try going out at the mall.

Stayed at this hotel for a weekend as it was the cheapest around and near to the olympic stadium. Had a wedding party stay here, so my guests could go sightseeing afterwards. Its located about 10-15min walk from the westfield shopping centre and  20min via train to central london.Rooms are clean but there was not much of a view from where I was staying.Breakfast was free so did not expect much so was not dissappointed.

I am a Platinum Loyalty Card holder for IHG and have been for many years.So have stayed in a great many franchised hotels in the UK and a few overseas.This is quite an odd experience for me, having stayed here since it was opened, sporadically.The decor in places is already a little 'worn'. My room last month had a hole in the bathroom door which was about fist sized, and various fittings are failing in the rooms.This one has a tv stand that was canted over and loose - thought if I moved it would fall.Having smapled several rooms now there is a pattern of poor maintenance here.The aircon was ineffectual during out one week heat wave too, this was reported but not fixed.Room service standards are extremely good and the team always jovial and friendly to guests.But where this business fails consistently is the quality of its food and service.You will pay more than any top restaurant chain in the nearby Westfield. A lot more.And the service is dire, expect to wait no less than thirty minutes, every time for poorly cooked and fairly 'synthetic' meal akin to any night in a Wetherspoon pub.Nothing wrong with Wetherspoon either, I love a budget pub, but contrast a pint and a curry there against the same food, smaller portions and served more slowly for three times the cost?Breakfast in 'free' only becuase you simply couldn't charge for it. I always forgo it and head to a nice private cafe nearby.It's surprising you can still get away with poor quality like this in 2012.The headline room rates now it's getting ever nearer to games time are astonishing (very high).I'm afraid this will be one of a few hotels that won't go the distance in Stratford once 2012 is a distant memory.The are juts a few parking slots, an nothing nearby. There are no alternative eateries in the vacinity.The hotel has no additional facilities at all.With better franchises less than a mile away, and an excellent Premiere Inn right beside the best food in town, why bother coming here at all?Previous reviews are interesting, and many from infrequent visitors to London.Which is possibly why they are happy to rate mediocre quite highly.

I stayed there with family for our vacation, hotel is 10 min walk from station.Staff is excellent ( specially who work late night) but one old lady ( i think she was a duty manager) was very rude and was avoiding us.Breakfast choices are excellent but Mgt should give more attention on cleaning tables specially thinking Olympics is just next door.

column9: A nice hotel near Olympic Park
column10: We were trying to keep the cost of visiting London down so, we picked a hotel in east London. The rooms were clean and efficient(no frills). The breakfast had something for everyone and the staff was very helpful to us! I'd stay here again!

Stayed last night and was pleasantly suprised. The location is Dubai themed - lots of development going on in preparation for the Olympics. This hotel is within walking distance of the Olympic Stadium and 10 minutes from Stratford station so really very well located. Check in was efficient and easy, we were located on the 6th floor. The decor of the hotel is nice and modern and there is a touch screen stand which is very nice. The room was lovely and the bathroom of a very high standard. One note (room626) the window fully opened even with the sticker saying it doesn't! Breakfast was a bit of a crazy time, no order and only half the breakfast available - rice krispies were good! Check out was smooth. Car parking is pretty expensive for a very small car park considering this is not city centre. Overall I would highly recommend this for a stay during the Olympics!

We stayed here for one night mainly due to the fact that it had its own private car park (¬£20 to park per day). The room was nice, big and clean, although the bed did seem a little small but this may be due to the fact that there seemed to be a lot of empty space in the room. Good location for visiting Westfield and for the Olympics and the breakfast was good, plenty of sausages, beans, eggs and croissants to help yourself to however the tables were all pretty dirty and we had to eat off our tray.We will stay here again if we visit the area, very comfortable sleep, good breakfast, location ideal for visiting the area and secure parking all for a very reasonable price.

This is a relatively new HIEX, with rooms and public areas of a high standard.  Big advantage is proximity to the DLR station, virtually across the street, giving access to London City Airport in around 20 mins.Rooms were of a good size, and bathrooms very nice.

first off don't expect to get any sleep till after 04.00, like trying to sleep in a car/lorrypark.tap fell off in the bathroom, response from staff,"you can have a free drink" i suppose that's to help you sleep ?plenty of other places to stay ,go there, even if it cost you more ,that is if you want to sleep?

Not the best, nicest location. Ate in restaraunt, food awful. The worst part was the language in bar, swearing a top of voice in clear earshot of families and staff who did nothing about it but carried on serving alcohol. You are an inconvenience to the staff, unfriendly.

Look, first of all this is a Holiday Inn Express, it's not a five star stay, bear this in mind when booking. I have looked at some of the other reviews, I cannot comment on the competence of the staff in general beyond checking in and checking out, this they achieved with no problem.I found the room to be quite comfortable, I was concerened about the room being at the front and overlooking Stratford High Street, I shouldn't have as the noise level was not a problem at all. The bed was comfy enough for an undisturbed sleep. I didn't spend a whole heap of time in the room beyond sleeping, but I would have been happy enough to.Breakfast was, well Express style breakfast - scrambled eggs, suasages, beans, a variety of pastries and croissants, cereals, fruit, yoghurt. Let's face it, for an included in the price breakfast it did the trick.But the overwhelming advantage of this hotel is it's location. Putting ther Olympic statdiium to one side for the moment; those who are not really familiar with London geography should note that Stratford is convinently on the Jubilee and Central tube lines, Overground rail services and the Docklands light railway. Liverpool Street and therefore the central business district is one stop by overground and a couple of stops by tube. In a nutshell, a brief journey out from central London can see the cost (at the moment) of your hotel significantly reduced with no real hassle in travelling back to town.However, this strength can actually be a weakness. Stratford is a hussling, busseling hotbed. There is nothing close by to stroll to to eat apart from the Westfield shopping centre. Stratford is 'being' redeveloped, it is far from redeveloped. Once this transformation is complete I can see the cost of this hotel being raised.Also, as somebody else pointed out, it isn't signposted from the station. It is a good ten minutes walk with light luggage, but I am sure this will change very soon. So, to the Olympic Stadium, it's right there. literally outside the door and down Carpenters road. As such and with HI being a major Olympic sponsor the hotel had Olympic athletes and other Olympic statdium associated clientelle (tradesmen!). The GB mens Waterpolo Team were there for some sort of meeting.In conclusion, I think that at the present time, whilst Stratford metamorphasises itself into...well what ever it becomes and the hotel is sort of stuck out on a limb. If you can live with the slightly dodgy, but should be expected breakfast and a ten minute stroll from the station, undirected and along a typical busy main road you really should consider this hotel. It's cost effective and really convenient for getting back into town.How it will change post Olympics, only time will tell.

column9: Good location with easy access to central London
column10: This was yet another typical Holiday Inn Express - nice, clean, good location. 25 minutes by metro to central London, the metro stop is 5-10 minutes walking distance from the hotel. Bus stop is outside the hotel, Bus. No. 25 takes you to Londong bridge area within 20 minutes.  The room was standard with 1 double bed and 1 sofa bed. Clean and nice. The breakfast was superb ! Overall we had a great stay, they have let us check out a bit later at no extra charge so we could relax a bit more before our flight. Thanks !

column9: below expectations for the incompetent staff
column10: We have recently spent five nights at the HIE in Stratford. The chain is one of our favourite ones and being a member of the Priority Club Rewards I thought I would have a stay just as great as at the other HIE hotels. I could not be more wrong. The hotel itself is not bad, it is clean and nice. Unfortunately nearly all the staff are incompetent, cold and careless.1) To start with we were given a communicating room. I mean inside our room there was a connecting door to the next room. The first night maybe because we were extremely tired we did not hear any particular noises just voices at a bearable level though. On Good Friday night instead goodness me!! Young men's loud voices, coarse laughters, wild screams. It seemed all that wild party going on was right inside our room. Needless to say we could no longer cope with that so rather than knocking on the connecting door and give the young lads a piece of my mind I rang up the reception. That must have been at around 11:30 pm and spoke to a receptionist who did not sound very willing to cooperate. However he reassured me saying he would soon call the room. In a nutshell he never called them, the phone did not ring in their room and they went on till 1 am when the three of us put some earplugs and fell asleep due to our tiredness. God knows when they stopped painting the town red. 2) One night we decided to have dinner at the hotel. It was around 9:30 pm and we saw some people sitting at the tables while eating their dinner. One lady was just getting her meals when we kindly approached the young waitress who was serving and taking orders. No sooner had I started saying we would like to have dinner than she interruped me saying 'It's too late now. No more dinners.' Provided that probably it might have been too late for the hotel policy but that's definitely not the way you should answer your paying customers. Not apologetic at all, not a single smile, nothing at all. Without any further questioning we just thanked her and walked off. We went to the next-door hotel Travelodge and it was about 9:45 pm by the time we asked their waiter if we could have dinner over there. Not only did he welcome us in a friendly way but said we could order anything we wanted. We then found out he was an Italian chap and  as we are Italian too we had a nice, long conversation. He told us that they regularly served the HIE guests as there seemed to be some problems over there.  3) One afternoon I was waiting for some very important documents from Italy. They had been sent to the hotel email address. When I went over to the reception to get them a very cold, acid and inconsiderate elderly lady receptionist with a French name said there was absolutely nothing under my name. As I was very sure that there was something for me I begged her to look one more time. Totally careless she said nothing once more. Not a smile, not a professional attitude. I called back an office back home and they confirmed that they had successfully sent me the document. Armed with patience I went back with a big smile to the old lady. At first she pretended to be busy at the bar after  some minutes she came to me and tried to say there was still nothing. Thanks to my endurance and patience after insisting she produced some papers. Not a single sorry, not a smile, no apologies at all. I still wonder how such rude people can work with guests at a hotel. 4) The mattresses are so soft you literally sink into them. Very uncomfortable, I had a terrible backache during all my stay. 5) The main channels on TV did not work. (BBC 1, BBC 2 etc)The breakfast is good though even if something is over you had better forget it. They won't bring it back. I asked for a banana as the last one had been taken by a lady before me. During the 10/15 minutes I had my breakfast no bananas came at all. It was  certainly the case to go bananas!!! To end up I gave two points rather than one as it deserved  just because there is a Lithuanian girl Edita at the reception who was the only nice and efficient member of staff, really helpful indeed!!

column9: An okay stay, great location and price but just that darn fire alarm!
column10: Having read a few of the reviews on here and finding a good price of around ¬£82 per night we decided to stay here for 2 nights for an event at the 02 arena. It was a pretty good choice and having stayed at a HI Express in Edinburgh I kinda knew what to expect. Simple but clean, modern accommodation with inclusive breakfast.We checked in at around 1:30pm and the room was ready straight away, room 217 on the 2nd floor. I was a bit apprehensive at first as I usually prefer a high floor room but it was just right, around the corner from the lift so not much walking and not facing the road out front so there was not much noise.The room did face a wall but on looking to the left there was plenty of light and a view of a school playing field, but we did experience a strange whirring noise at times which sounded like a fan going around on the floor below but managed to get to sleep okay although the bed was very soft. The shower was pretty big and only varied in temperature at times and wasn't annoying in anyway. The bathroom and bedroom were spotlessly clean and it was nice they provided free tea and coffee in the room that got refilled daily.I have seen a few complaints about breakfast but we arrived each morning around 9am and had no problem getting a table with clean plates/cutlery and food topped up as I know some hotels wind down the breakfast near the end of service. There was a small selection of hot items inc. scrambled eggs, baked beans, and sausages and felt they could have not made so many beans and put a tray of bacon or hash browns out instead. There was also pastries, croissants, mini baguettes, muller yogurts and a variety of spreads for toast.We came back later in the day with Stratford station only a 10 minute walk away. The high street which you walk down is okay and we walked back late at night with no problems and it really is so easy to get to, just past the travelodge. For safety I think they should have key card access for the lifts like the Premier Inn as anyone could access the floors.After a peaceful nights sleep we were abruptly woken by a fire alarm at 7:35am... not impressed! I had heard previously that this hotel does have a fire alarm test on a Thursday so thought not much of the fire alarm. We decided to get up and find warm clothing and just as we were about to head out the door the fire alarm stopped. We had no phone call from reception to alert of what was going on and then 5 mins later another alarm went off in another block, now surely for safety reasons the whole building should be on the same fire alarm in case the fire spread but im no expert. I eventually called reception to see if we still needed to leave the room but all they did was apologise, not explain why it happened and thought there is just no point trying to get back to sleep! We had breakfast, again quite quiet but I guess people went back to sleep and checked out. I would stay here again if the price is right but now that the premier inn is closer to the station I may stay there to avoid any early morning wake up calls!
My mum and I stayed at this hotel for a recent shopping trip.  It is within walking distance of the shopping centre (about 10 minutes) and it clean, spacious and good value for money.

column9: May be a Holiday Inn Express, but don't expect express breakfast or service.
column10: My daughter booked this hotel for myself and grand daughter as a pre birthday treat for me.  We arrived at Stratford station, and with the Olympics coming you would have thought there would have been signs to hotels, but no.  We eventually found the hotel, but as we were early (11.30 a.m.) were unable to book in, but were told we could leave our bags, and the receptionist would be "over with a key" to unlock the luggage room.  After 15 minutes we asked again, and she did eventually come over.  On our return at 7.00 p.m. the check in was quick, our room was very clean and the beds comfortable, but the room was so hot, and we just couldn't fathom how to turn off the heating, even a phone call to reception didn't really help. We resorted to opening the window, not good as our room was at the front, and London is a city that 'never sleeps'!!  Breakfast was an absolute farce, no clean plates, no knives, they just kept running out of everything, even food!  No-one to check anybody into breakfast, so you could just walk in off the street for a free meal.  Tables full of dirty crockery, we struggled to find a table anyway as the place was heaving.  Absolute chaos. If this had been our first experience of a Holiday Inn, I would never use them again, but fortunately former experiences have been better.  If they can't cope with the volume of people now, God help anyone who books in there for the Olympics!!

column9: If this was your first stay at a holiday inn express it would probably be your last
column10: The hotel was clean all round, but the slow reception service and appalling management of the so called express breakfast buffet (should have been the slow buffet) let the place down. How they'll cope when the Olympics come to town, I'll never know!

I stayed at this hotel at the weekend whilst taking part in the Olympic Park Run.  Check-in was swift and the staff we very friendly and cheerful.  The hotel is brand new with the rooms being very clean and comfortable (bed was a bit soft, my partner and I tended to roll towards each other in the middle a lot!)  Breakfast was plentiful it kept me going right through my run and I didn't eat again until 9.30pm!!It's location is perfect for the Olympics and anyone who adores shopping as its's a 4 to 8 min walk from Stratford Station and Westfield shopping centre.  I brought ear plugs with me as I can't stand London traffic, and I popped them straight in so can't comment on any traffic noise, however my partner did comment on the noise from next door at 3am!Overall I would recommend this hotel to everyone, esp if your coming to the Games in the summer.

column9: nice hotel shame about the beds
column10: I stayed in this hotel with work as we were at a show at Earls Court and its only 15 mins away on the underground and much cheaper.everything about the hotel was great other than the beds, they were soft like a sponge and if you move you are going to fall out. Other memeber of staff in my company had the same problem so none of us slept well.but the hotel is great other wise, you cant hear the road outside or anything else.

column9: And the first Gold Medal goes to...........Holiday Inn Express Stratford.
column10: We arrived early on Saturday (midday) I had booked 2 rooms one for my Wife and myself and one for my daughter and boyfriend .Check in is not till after 14.00 but after enquiring we were told we could have our rooms and continued to dump our stuff off and head off into London (Stratford Station and Westfield Shopping centre 4 minutes walk away).The whole experience was totally professional and friendly ,the rooms are really lovely and spotlessly clean. The shower is fantastic too with a plentiful supply of instant hot water.After a good nights sleep we had a nice breakfast with plenty on offer such as sausages,eggs,beans croissant etc etc.Complementary newspapers were also on offer throughout our stay too.Summing up this is a really nice Hotel and will be a great place to stay for the Olympics and hope they continue to maintain their Gold Medal Status.Thank you for making our Mothers Day weekend an enjoyable one.

Very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the room - painted in tasteful colours with lots of attention to details - air conditioning, plug by the bed, full Freeview on the TV, Kettle with decent brand tea/coffee supplied. The bathroom is spotlessly clean and finished to a high specification, and I know it's only a small thing, but I really appreciated that there are lots of shelves in the shower! Check-in was good and professional and I feel really relaxed after spending the evening in the room. Price was good too, prepay, ¬£60 for a Sat night in London.About a five minute walk from the new Westfield shopping centre and Stratford station. The only thing missing is free wi-fi which still hasn't arrived in the UK which is baffling in this day and age (have stayed in many HIExpress in USA which provide it as standard)

I'd only stayed at a Holiday Inn once before this time, and then I didn't really pay attention to it as it was before an early flight, but this time round I was absolutely stunned by how amazing it was. Now, I've never stayed at any fancy five star hotels, but I've got to say, they can't possibly top a Holiday Inn.The room was spotless, absolutely beautiful. And what I liked was that they gave you enough pillows for the amount of people sharing the room (unlike a Travelodge who give you thin pillows, and only three...) and there was a choice of soft or firm, which was wonderful.The bathroom was lovely, shiny and beautifully clean. Hot water ran through easily, and the shower was lovely. Every morning that we were there, we were entitled to a complementary breakfast which was also very nice. This Holiday Inn was also in a great location in Stratford, with just a mere five minute walk to Stratford Station, with a small shopping mall opposite the station.Overall, I had a wonderful experience at this Holiday Inn, I would stay there again and again, and would definitely recommened this place to everybody who will listen!

column9: Good hotel and very polite staff!
column10: This bucks the trend that London hotels don't have polite and helpful staff. The staff are attentive, polite and run a clean modern hotel. My second visit here and will keep using it. Breakfast is excellent and lots of choice.

Most central London hotels in this price range are tiny, old, and dumpy.  For the trouble of a few extra minutes on the tube, this place is shiny new and nicely outfitted.  Nothing fancy, but comfortable and a good breakfast too.  Definitely worth the trouble to travel a little farther.

Close to Stratford underground station and shopping mall (approx. 10min. by foot). Tube will take you to Oxford street station in 20 minutes. So perfect for visiting London. Check- in was smooth. Professional and friendly staff. Room was clean, well maintained, nicely decorated, comfortable beds.Small bathroom but well equipped. Coffee/tea making facilities available. Rooms at street side can be bit noisy at night when you are a light sleeper. Breakfast was very basic. Eggs were finished at 9.15. No cheese or meat available.Breafast area was in main entrance hall. Cold atmosfhere. For less fussy travellers, its a good priced hotel, on convenient location. You can save good money by staying here instead of choosing a high priced hotel downdown London.

column9: Brand New Express by Holiday Inn
column10: The fact that the hotel has around one year of existence its awesome: carpets, curtains, furniture, towels...everything is brand new!The reason we've chosen this hotel was the location: direct bus from stansted airport, close to the future olympic city, 10 minutes walking from the tube/railway station and from the fantastic Westfield Shopping Centre (if you are into the Olympics go to John Lewis 5th floor and from there you have an amazing view of the constructions that are being made).The hotel was quiet, with the right type of people, check in and out were quick, breakfast was quit good (variety and quality) and the area is bright and with plenty of place to sit.The rooms were nicely cleaned everyday although garbage bin wasnt changed during our whole saty (4nights).Shampoo/shower gel are provided to you. And there are also coffee tea facilities in the room.Oh, and plenty of tv channels!Stratford is a lovely, blooming area and you wont regret staying here.

We stayed during our visit to London.The Manager (Harshed) was very helpful in accommodating all our requests and guiding us places to visit.Breakfast was excellent, selection of coffee and Hot chocolate for kids was a excellent choice.We enjoyed our stay ,Next visit we will book it again.

column9: Nice, clean, value for money with a good 10-15 min walk from Stratford Station.
column10: Good location if you are going to stay during the Olympics. Stratford station is newly renovated with a newly opened Westfield Mall next to it.40 min from Stratford to Oxford Circut by the tube or 60 min by bus

column9: Quick visit to Stratford, East London
column10: We wanted a couple of nights break in London and got a great room deal through Late Rooms.The hotel is fairly new, I presume built for London 2012 Olympics, and needing finishing touches (eg some plastic covers on bathroom fixtures and only one of two lifts in working order)However the room was clean and comfortable, great bed! Breakfast was self service with a hostel type approach but was adequate. Clearing up a bit slapdash with trays and residue left about, even room service trays in the hallways.Parking onsite is great but limited and not too expensive for London in my experience.All staff we met were polite and helpful. Location is good for the new Westfield shopping centre and will be good for access to the Olympics but not very good directions to stations and amenities when leaving the hotel.

Stayed for three nights when attending an event at the O2 Arena.  Directions on website from tube station aren't great.  Was told Stratford High Street was closest tube, which it is, but no other directions, so turned the wrong way getting there on my first night and a five mins walk ended up being 25 mins which wasn't fun after a 12 hour day with a suitcase.  There's only one small "convenience" store nearly opposite the hotel, other than that, the hotel is in the middle of a road of offices and after being at O2 all day, I didn't want to walk up to the Westfield Centre to eat.  However, the hotel itself is good, the room was spacious (and reasonable price) and very clean.  Slightly noisy as my room faced the main road, but I'm a country bumpkin, so very noise aware.  Nice breakfast (although a little limited), but good coffee, which is always my main priority!

When i booked i knew it would be for a twin or double room but when i got to the request box i did request a double room. So when we arrived we were given a twin room! But no problem as it was soon changed to a double room. Cannot fault the size or cleanliness of the room with tea & coffee. The mattress was exceptionally soft and sunk about a foot when getting into bed. The wet room was equipped for a wheelchair user which was fine but we were on the top floor! At 00:30 the smoke alarm went off & we had to vacate the hotel, which for able bodied people was fine but as the lift was not in use because of the fire alarm a wheelchair user would never have been able to get down the 92 steps. Fortunately it was not a fire but an alarm fault (so we were told in the morning). We were able to go back into the hotel after about 20 minutes. yes...back up the 92 steps. We had to keep the window closed to tone down the noise of the traffic and all the sirens throughout the night, that was without our three fire engines. Breakfast was ok ish. But my biggest gripe was having a tiny car park with a fee of ¬£20. It is very close to the Olympic site with about a mile walk to the new shopping centre.

On arrival I was allocated a room that was already occupied and it seemed to go downhill from there. While the hotel is clean and the rooms good organization was not good. I was with a friend who is vegan and every day of our week long stay meant a struggle for breakfast despite prior organization. The biggest gripe though was the wifi policy. As a conference hotel, which was how we were sold it, the expense and lack of flexibility of Internet access was appalling. It is not possible to buy, for example, 24 hours of access and use it across several days. Once logged in you must use it all. This hotel is very close to the Olympic area and will seriously need to lift it's game!

I booked this hotel on Expedia for 9/10 November at ¬£158 for the Wednesday night and ¬£88 for the Thursday night which averaged out to ¬£120 per night. I called to confirm our reservation for a 'smoking room with two twin beds' the night before we arrived and was assured that everything was in order. We checked in at approximately 1:00pm the following day and were told that our 'non-smoking room with one double bed' wouldn't be available until 2:00pm. Obviously the system broke down but the gentleman behind the counter was very helpful and quickly sorted things out for us. We were in room #609 on the top floor which provided a view of the unremarkable east London landscape. The room was small but clean and contained a television, a desk area with a chair, and a kettle with coffee and tea. We found the beds comfortable and each came with two pillows tagged with 'firm' and 'soft' although we couldn't tell the difference. The bathroom was spotless but there are no amenities. The soap and shampoo are one in the same and dispersed from a wall mounted unit in the shower. The towels were a nice size but disappointingly thin. There was no mini-bar or in-room safe, although there are safe deposit boxes in the lobby - there may be a fee attached to use them, we didn't bother. The Expedia website lists 'Wireless Internet Access' as one of the hotel's room amenities but there's a ¬£15 per day charge for that and we passed. The computer in the lobby, if used for less than 10 minutes per day, is free... but longer than that and the ¬£15 charge is applied to your bill. The hotel provides breakfast from 6:30 - 9:30 which is comprised of scrambled eggs, sausage and beans, (it's a British thing), along with the typical assortment of cold items: cereals, breads, fruit. The sausage was extremely poor quality but everything else was quite nice and the hot chocolate from the machine dispenser was surprisingly good. The Stratford International Rail Station offers both the Central and Jubilee tube lines for getting into the city center and the station is roughly a ten minute walk from the hotel. The new Stratford High Street station for the Docklands Light Railway is much closer and very convenient if using City Airport. We knew we were signing up to a budget hotel and we had a pleasant stay here; the staff were terrific and everything was clean and comfortable.

We have arrived after a very long flight to London at 11.00. am. We asked the reception for a possible room, they sent us away with a very rude manner ( a "big" lady). Ok we decided to put our luggages in, as they told they do not have any room which is already usable. No problem. BUT!! In 2 minutes arrived another couple and they could check in!! What kind of hospitality is that?  I can tell that is not! The Greek Lady was helpful all the other receptionists behaved like we are unneccessary things in their lives. They sent us to Stratford International as it is the closest station. Stratford High Street is much closer, it is in half way, we realised ourselves! Room was ok, except there is no safe, no fridge, even no toilet brush :) The internet is for charge, the bed is too soft, if you sit down on it, it goes down 50 cms, funny anway.I have asked for an iron 4 times, after that they sent me an iron from the 1980's  :) Breakfast is terrible, it is good if you would loose some weight. What they are preparing is without any taste. The apples were fine.If you would like to have a shower  take care: if you set for example 38 degrees Celsius , it is sure that it will change suddenly to very hot after that very cold. So you have to be careful if you would have a shower more than 10 seconds.We have booked a double and they've given a twin as "that is the standard room" OMG!So for 500 USD / 2 nights it was almost a nightmare.

A typical HI, nice rooms, smoking rooms, good food and bar. I do have a problem with a hotel that you have to pay an extra ¬£20 for parking though!! Especially when its a hotel with about a 100 rooms and only parking for about 20 cars....If I built a house with 4 bedrooms the council tells me I have to have parking for at least 2 cars....How come a hotel can open with loads of rooms but only a few parking spaces......Other than that though its a nice hotel but I won't be staying again

Stayed here 1 night on 24th October. Very good location, right next to the Olympic stadium and 5 minutes walk to the Westfield shopping centre. About 20 minutes by tube or main line train to central london. Very friendly staff and spacious well appointed rooms. not much traffic noise. Good selection for breakfast

We had a very clean room, with everything you could need for an overnight stay.  It was very comfortable and our room at the back was quiet.  The reception staff were helpful about local transport.  Breakfast was in a light and airy space which was nice.  It was self-service, not great, but OK, served the purpose.

We stayed in the holiday inn express whilst it was being renervated last year.  Our room was modern.  During our 2 night stay we got locked out of our room due to  a fault in the new door.  All hotel staff were very accommodating and we were well looked after.  Including being given complimentry drinks and a nights stay for free!  Breakfast was very busy and basic.  Quite a way out but easily accessible by tube.  All in all a good hotel and an affordable price in london!

I booked into this hotel for two nights whilst working in Stratford and it was in an ideal location for Olympic Park.The hotel was generally well looked after. The breakfast was okay, but there were no wholegrain cereals and the waiting staff for breakfast were pretty unhelpful.All in all it does what is says on the tin and is nothing flashy but is better than you would expect for where it is.Expect to pay for wireless internet but the TV has a good selection of channels and you have the tea and coffee making facilities you would expect.

column9: Very good, clean and friendly hotel.
column10: This was a very affordable, very clean and comfortable hotel. The front desk staff was very attentive and always willing to help. I just happen to have taken the wrong adapter on this trip, and even though they sold new ones from a vending machine in the lobby, the staff was willing to offer me some adapters they had in the back. One of the most interesting things I found about staying at this hotel was the fact that I had to cross the Greenwich Meridian on the way to and from the Stratford tube station. You can get to walking distance of this hotel by taking the Heathrow Express to Paddington Station and then a combination of underground line stations will get you to the Stratford tube station three blocks away from the hotel. I did it upon arrival and departure from London. I would stay at this hotel again.

column9: Business hotel close to Olympic site
column10: I stay here most Wednesdays as I am a surveyor looking after several projects on the Olympic park. The hotel fully meets my needs and is very clean and comfortable. Close to Stratford station and the newly opened Westfield shopping centre. I have no reservations in recommending this hotel and I am confident that all who stay here will have an enjoyable experience. Breakfast / dining area open plan with reception but plenty of space; continental buffet breakfast is excellent. Not ate here as love the Thai cafe across the road.. Car parking is compact and not always guaranteed. All in all a great hotel with excellent staff..

I stayed here on business for 2 nights.  As this hotel is still relatively new, it didn't have that shabby feel that a lot of London hotels have.  The room was clean and comfortable and the staff very helpful and professional.  I ate in the restaurant on the first night, which is really just an extension of the reception area, but OK.  The menu is short and basic but the food is cooked well.It was an easy trip into central london in the mornings and a good opportunity to visit the Westfield shopping centre!Overall, I was very happy with my stay and would stay here again.

Whilst the room was clean and perfectly adequate, the beds used by HIE are the worst that I have ever had the misfortune to encounter.  At ¬£74 per night, I would expect to be able to sleep comfortably.  The mattress was too soft, coupled with being on top of a partly-sprung bed base; this made for a night of tossing and turning trying to get some sleep.Overall, I think that this particular hotel is perhaps not managed as well as it could be.  One of the lifts was out of order throughout the duration of our stay, the lavatories on the ground floor near the bar were disgusting, and the ashtray outside the front door was overflowing.In the corridor outside our room, there was a leak from the ceiling that dripped into a plastic container.  We spoke to the duty manager about the sleep quality and were told that he had not had any complaints, and considering that on the HIE feedback form there is no question relating to sleep quality, I am not surprised!We wrote to HIE to complain on returning home but three days later, no response (not exactly what I would call top-notch customer service).  Unless you like to sleep on marshmallows, I would avoid this hotel completely.

I have to say if this had been the first Holiday Inn Express I visited it may well have been the last.  Yes, it was reasonable (after negotiation), yes clean and the staff very good.  So very much under pressure I think, by the manager who sat every day in the bar on the laptop.  Every question or complaint was answered with a look over my shoulder to the manager to see if shehad heard and I am sure concerned about the answer given.There was a fire alarm one night of my stay.  The evacuation was pitiful, guests were unsure what to do and had to shoulder charge a double fire exit to get it to open.No roll call, and in fact a guest took over the job to ensure everyone was out.  Once the all clear was given everyone piled back in, even though the alarm was still going off intermittently.  Was it another alarm?  Fortunately not, just the fact the staff and the manager didn't know or could not, reset the alarm.I understand this hotel is run by London Inns; I would feel the brand was being damaged by this hotel if I was part of the Holiday Inn Group.  I decamped to the Ibis in the end.  Maybe not so well appointed but the staff were great and the breakfast offer much more civilised.  The Premier Inn at Westfield really will take up so much custom, the Holiday Inn Express will need to up its game.  The Olympics might provide a captured market, that is a short term win though.  Customer service should work top down...

column9: Clean room with good service and helpful staff.
column10: Stayed with the family for a week exploring London. Breakfast was simple but enough to start the day with. 10 minute away from Stratford Station. Major construction and renovation at the station to get ready for the Olympic. Westfield and M&S next to the station will be ready by October. 35 minutes away buy Central Line to the Heart of London.
